posts.cooked:
Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 3 million users.

image 959×1761 119 KB

image 1252×1810 117 KB

image 1252×1810 117 KB

For a while now I’ve been frustrated by the reusability of our team’s previous elevators. In theory, an elevator should be a readily reusable mechanism across years, with only a few overall dimension changes and gear ratio adjustments needed to make a 2022 climber into a 2018 cube placer. A variety of factors in the design have meant that each elevator has many small but time-consuming changes to work past the interferences introduced by each new use case. Each part of the elevator was competing for the same space, gussets, rigging, backstrap mounting, etc. With this in mind, the goal of this project was to separate and compact every subsystem in the elevator as much as reasonably possible.

Features:

-Capstan driven, continuous rigged, two-stage elevator -In tube rigging, -bearing blocks function also as rigging pulley mounts -tube connector block construction -gearboxes serve a dual purpose as triangular support for the base stage -ratchet and bungee tensioning system -clip-on spacers between bearings for easy assembly

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
DunaganM:

-In tube rigging

I would think long and hard about this, is this something you really want to assemble, run, and maintain over a season?

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Looks pretty good at first glance.  My 2 cents:

“capstan” (dyneema rope) rigging is really hard to get right in my experience.  It’s really easy for the rope to run off the reel, or get slack and tangle.  I would consider using chain - you could get rid of the whole tensioning system altogether.

for the similar reason, cascade rigging is much easier to get working well than continuous.  You don’t have to rely on gravity to keep the middle stage at a given spot.  Running the rope inside the tube is particularly challenging (but good on you if you pull it off)

Are those custom bearing blocks?  Because if so (and if you haven’t made them before) I’d recommend buying them instead.  There’s so many good COTS options now - there’s zero reason to reinvent the wheel.

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked:
This is a really great design idea! I love the attention to detail on everything.

Some thoughts:

I strongly recommend using the MKCAD design library for any FRC projects in Onshape, as it’ll make the process of getting not-broken hardware into your assembly way easier.

The ultra-low-profile screws on your bearing blocks are just begging to be rounded out at a critical time. I would recommend only going as low as normal low-profile screws, and if you have to cut a bearing to avoid interference, so be it.

Your bearing blocks are currently a PITA to fabricate, but luckily with a few small changes they can be improved. (1): Split the nub on the end into a separate, COTS spacer part, such as McM 92510A460 . (2): Save yourself a facing operation by making the thickness of the bearing block a “normal” value, such as .375" or .500", letting you make the blocks from bar stock. (3): Remove the groove and nub on the inside face, using a COTS spacer to separate out the bearing and just adding an extra screw to retain the block.

Your spools shouldn’t be “combs” - that won’t help control the rope winding. Instead, the grooves in your spools should either be nonexistent (if you’re OK with introducing a spring to take up any mismatch in lengths) or helical.

I like the current way the gearbox is set up. You can save on some hardware and complexity by making your pulley-mounting-screws go through the gearbox as well to mount it. This also means you can cut out some locknuts. If you don’t do this, make sure that you have clearance to get a wrench around those tightly-spaced locknuts.

It looks like all your spacers are custom parts. You can cut down on complexity by using COTS spacers - this may require you to move to inch-standard bearings, but in my opinion it’s much wiser to use inch-bearings in FRC anyway.

Pay some attention to designing for assembly. A number of parts in the elevator are very hard to access by hand, and some screw heads are completely unreachable when the elevator is fully assembled. Every layer of disassembly adds anywhere from one to ten minutes of disassembly time to get at key parts of your robot, so making all the hardware accessible is critical to reducing your robot’s downtime in the pits.

I recommend buying a handful of pulley-bearings and testing them all out in person before committing to the pulleys you use. I personally really like these for the task of carrying 1/8" rope, because you can carry them with a # 10 screw.

Firstly, thank you for your time and input.

A little more background on previous designs we’ve tried: this year we ran a capstan system of almost exactly the same drum design. IMG_20220228_220258943|666x500 IMG_20220220_194601718 3456×4608 2.7 MB

IMG_20220220_194601718 3456×4608 2.7 MB

IMG_20220220_194601718 3456×4608 2.7 MB

At the beginning of the season we had a lot of trouble keeping tension in the line but with some help from 3310 we switched to a pre stretched dyneema they pointed us toward, and switched the extension springs we had for tensioning out for surgical tubing. Once we did those two things we never had another problem with it and never in the season did we experience the line tangle or skip out of the grooves.

We have built cascade elevators in the past using the chain method, but for an elevator that is meant to fill many roles, continous seems to fit the bill better as it  doesn’t suffer from the same force multiplication as you increase stages, you can run a cascade with string and two different diameter drums to solve that problem but then you’re more complex than continuous.

Running the line in the tube was not a decision made lightly, the main driving factor was the ability to couple it with the bearings already in place and delete a boatload of parts and space.

Yes those are custom bearing blocks along with everything else. There are a few reasons for this. First, none of the cots ones on the market quite fit exactly like I wanted and making them custom allows for a lot of small optimizations. Second, with our teams manufacturing ability making custom parts that are already designed vs ordering and waiting is just about a wash in terms of time, especially considering how fast some products sell out.

Thank you for the feedback!

We do use MKCAD and it’s amazing! I couldn’t find some of the metric fasteners I needed in their library (I may have just missed them).

We do use MKCAD and it’s amazing! I couldn’t find some of the metric fasteners I needed in their library (I may have just missed them).

Ultra low profile screws are definitely not ideal, I’m hoping it won’t be an issue though as the intent is that on assembly those screws are installed with red Loctite to make the block and those bearings one unit, any service to the elevator requiring the removal of a stage is then done by removing the block entirely. we used this method in 2022 on a slightly different set of custom bearing blocks and it worked just fine.

Ultra low profile screws are definitely not ideal, I’m hoping it won’t be an issue though as the intent is that on assembly those screws are installed with red Loctite to make the block and those bearings one unit, any service to the elevator requiring the removal of a stage is then done by removing the block entirely. we used this method in 2022 on a slightly different set of custom bearing blocks and it worked just fine.

The bearing blocks are a PITA to machine, I count one facing op, one profiling op, and a fixture plate to do the bosses. You know what’s more of a PITA? small spacers. After 6 years of being pit crew, I have had just about enough of small spacers that are impossible to get into the right place and then fall into the bowels of the robot never to be seen again just as you were about to put the bolt through.

The bearing blocks are a PITA to machine, I count one facing op, one profiling op, and a fixture plate to do the bosses. You know what’s more of a PITA? small spacers. After 6 years of being pit crew, I have had just about enough of small spacers that are impossible to get into the right place and then fall into the bowels of the robot never to be seen again just as you were about to put the bolt through.

I believe you’re thinking of a conventional wind on, wind off spool system, this is not that. This is capstan, see World's Fastest Grappling Hook Winch! (HACKLORIAN: Chapter 6) - YouTube

I believe you’re thinking of a conventional wind on, wind off spool system, this is not that. This is capstan, see World's Fastest Grappling Hook Winch! (HACKLORIAN: Chapter 6) - YouTube

The bolts for the pulleys being separate from the gearbox was a deliberate choice. The gearbox is mounted at two points only, so you can remove one bolt and pivot it up in order to get more room to string the capstan. without this feature, it would be near impossible to rig the elevator.

The bolts for the pulleys being separate from the gearbox was a deliberate choice. The gearbox is mounted at two points only, so you can remove one bolt and pivot it up in order to get more room to string the capstan. without this feature, it would be near impossible to rig the elevator.

Back to my opinions on spacers, the spacers are all custom 3d printed this choice was made so that they could be clipped on from the side with the bolt already in place. This was inspired by 2881’s 2022 intake in which they used the same system to space their roller wheels at even intervals. Additionally, since they are all small parts printed without support, with very little requirement for precision it should be easy to crank out a whole bunch overnight. As far as inch bearings go I tried for many hours to source ones that would work, but I just could not find the combination of radial and V-groove bearing that would work at a reasonable price point. Additionally, most inch bearings are designed with fractional id’s which means you either have to sand your bolts (done that, not fun) or use shoulder bolts which gets expensive fast.

Back to my opinions on spacers, the spacers are all custom 3d printed this choice was made so that they could be clipped on from the side with the bolt already in place. This was inspired by 2881’s 2022 intake in which they used the same system to space their roller wheels at even intervals. Additionally, since they are all small parts printed without support, with very little requirement for precision it should be easy to crank out a whole bunch overnight. As far as inch bearings go I tried for many hours to source ones that would work, but I just could not find the combination of radial and V-groove bearing that would work at a reasonable price point. Additionally, most inch bearings are designed with fractional id’s which means you either have to sand your bolts (done that, not fun) or use shoulder bolts which gets expensive fast.

Hidden bolts: This is one of my least favorite parts of this design, second only to small spacers on my list of maintenance nightmares are hard-to-reach bolts. The first reason I am okay with it the way it is is that all the hidden bolts are in the tube connectors which is the least likely place to need maintenance. It should be noted that every bolt will be blue loctited and allowed the full cure time. The second reason I’m okay with this is that I think the alternatives are worse. putting gussets on the outside creates endless interferences with the bearings and was one of the main reasons I decided to try something different.

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked:
DunaganM:

After 6 years of being pit crew, I have had just about enough of small spacers that are impossible to get into the right place and then fall into the bowels of the robot never to be seen again just as you were about to put the bolt through.

you are going to love these bad boys . no need for spacers if you use them (make note of the load ratings though)
I do love these things! too bad they never seem to make them in the sizes I need, and they’re usually expensive. Maybe that means I need to drop some constraints

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Interesting!  So, your winching is going to be dependent on keeping the line tight for pulling ability.  You might look at a die spring (compression) as a tensioner, with an eyebolt through the middle to couple the line to it.  We’ve used this on VERY large scale as a tension amplifier on a wireline winch.  They key bit is that you need to maintain tension on the “slack” side so the capstan has something to amplify.  At some point you get into trouble where the wireline can take more tension than it can survive on the spool; the wire gets crushed.  Sorry about the low-res image. New Wireline Extreme Pull Systems Reduce Gulf of Mexico Deepwater Fishing Incidents Saving Operators 12 Days of Deepwater Rig Time and USD 9 Million | SPE/IADC Drilling Conference and Exhibition | OnePetro

As for the bearing blocks, you might just square up the round extrusion/integral spacer to make them easier to machine.  You don’t need a perfectly round thing touching the bearing, you just need to not touch the moving part.

I’d also plan in some rubber bump stops, but that’s my paranoia talking

A sneaky thing would be to 3DP some mating combs to keep your cable in the capstans when the tension is off to make assembly easier.
Love all of these suggestions! Thank you!  I’ve definitely thought about trying to include some of soft stops between stages, but I haven’t come up with a method I like yet.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
What ensures that the carriage assembly and two large rectangular frames are built sufficiently flat and remain that way? An impact could cause the tubes to shift slightly relative to the blocks leading to some of the assemblies to not be flat and jam.

I’m thinking back to a previous year where the team my son was on built an elevator where the carriage could not freely move up and down because it was built twisted enough that it jammed when first installed. A lot of remedial work was required to make it sufficiently flat so it could move.

Good question! All the aluminum parts that makup the frame are machined on a 3-axis cnc Mill. The tube blocks are the main thing promoting square assembly, they slide into the tube as a fairly close fit and then mate with the extruded face of the other tube. It won’t be perfect but it’s definitely better than previous elevators we’ve built that just relied on the holes in the gussets which were a free fit, and done on a much less precise cnc router. And they worked fine.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: During assembly you could put some bearing retaining compound between the mating aluminum surfaces, put the frame section on a flat surface, and tighten. Bonus points if you can squeeze in some corner braces on the frames Rubber feet for enclosures work for bumpers and normally have a hole and a washer mounded in them.  You could space them up and have a matching window in the frame so that it bumps the far side of the tube.  That minimizes the clearance you need to build in for the bumpers.  You do need to plan in some over travel to squeeze them…

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
The issue I am concerned about is the vertical tubes shifting relative to the 4 screws attaching them to the blocks. The holes in the tubes for the screws will have some clearance that will allow some shifting around. Any small shift is magnified by the length of the tubes. The lengths of the tubes also allow a lot of leverage to be applied to the screws when there is a force or impact on the structure. These forces can come from contact with other robots or field structures or they can come from the mass of the carriage, any mechanisms mounted on the carriage and any game pieces held by the mechanisms as the robot accelerates or decelerates, especially when the elevator is fully extended.

image 707×530 72 KB

image 707×530 72 KB

image 707×530 72 KB

If one is using gussets on the outer surfaces, they would tend to clamp the vertical and horizontal tubes together and possibly resist torquing of the structure better.

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked: I’ve done a lot of different bumper solutions for elevators, and this is the one I’ve liked the most. The idea is that you just slap it onto a surface and call it a day.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
DunaganM:

I couldn’t find some of the metric fasteners I needed in their library (I may have just missed them).

What metric fasteners were you looking for? The Onshape standard content library is pretty comprehensive and should have most fasteners you need. MKCad doesn’t really do fasteners aside from nylock nuts (missing from standard content)

posts.name: Martin Pirringer
posts.cooked:
How about a rack and pinion setup. Double helical double sided one or twin setup.

The rack is double sided to eliminate deflection. And is extendable at the core you can insert a 1/2 in square tubing either aluminum or steel either tube or solid that takes most the force, Self aligning to a degree as its double helical the top and bottom gears mesh together and with the ones in front and back so you got 4 gears per double rack engaging with each double rack at a time  plus 6 to keep everything in sync. As they are helical and involute you get at least 3 teeth per gear or 12 on the rack engaged at any given time.

And its 3dp. 20220220_1613171 4624×2604 2.85 MB 20220219_1921341 2604×4624 1.56 MB 20220220_1613351 4624×2604 2.88 MB 20220220_1645571 2604×4624 1.71 MB

20220220_1613171 4624×2604 2.85 MB

20220220_1613171 4624×2604 2.85 MB

20220219_1921341 2604×4624 1.56 MB

20220219_1921341 2604×4624 1.56 MB

20220220_1613351 4624×2604 2.88 MB

20220220_1613351 4624×2604 2.88 MB

20220220_1645571 2604×4624 1.71 MB

20220220_1645571 2604×4624 1.71 MB

The rigging setup on this will not perform reliably for several reasons. While in general I like continuous rigging with rope due to its low weight and price, it has to be done correctly to get the benefits without introducing headaches with rigging

Having only .1in of separation between stages does not leave much clearance for rope. You can only run 1/16th uhmwpe rope which when climbing with two ropes has almost no safety factor between the load experienced when climbing and the maximum working load of the rope. I would suggest allowing the design to run 7/64ths to allow climbing without worries.

Having only .1in of separation between stages does not leave much clearance for rope. You can only run 1/16th uhmwpe rope which when climbing with two ropes has almost no safety factor between the load experienced when climbing and the maximum working load of the rope. I would suggest allowing the design to run 7/64ths to allow climbing without worries.

The motors on the elevator are not mechanically linked to each other. Slight differences in their feeding can cause the system to bind up. While running a shaft to link the motors is infeasiable here, there is a second method of mechanically linking the motors. Instead of having two motors on each side, you can replace one of the gearboxes with point to tie the extension rope off and put both motors on the other side so they both spool a single rope than runs on both sides. However, this requires spooling up twice and much string and creates an additional 2:1 reduction that will also have to be mirrored on the retract string. This also halves the number of spools and tensioning points that need to be maintained while taking any tensioning mechanisms off the carriage of the elevator.

The motors on the elevator are not mechanically linked to each other. Slight differences in their feeding can cause the system to bind up. While running a shaft to link the motors is infeasiable here, there is a second method of mechanically linking the motors. Instead of having two motors on each side, you can replace one of the gearboxes with point to tie the extension rope off and put both motors on the other side so they both spool a single rope than runs on both sides. However, this requires spooling up twice and much string and creates an additional 2:1 reduction that will also have to be mirrored on the retract string. This also halves the number of spools and tensioning points that need to be maintained while taking any tensioning mechanisms off the carriage of the elevator.

posts.name: Beachbotics
posts.cooked: We used something similar for 2018 PowerUp, except used straps instead of chain/cord.  Mechanically the setup worked great, the challenge was getting the gearing balanced enough to climb (power gearing) versus lifting the crate up to the platform (speed gearing). We error too much on power.  The two straps were powered by a single axle driven by a winch.  For robustness, both raise and lower cycles were powered.  We used harpoon tubing to allow the lowering strap to stretch, so the system wouldn’t bind or sag as the pulley diameter changes as the strapping winds on the pulley.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
@Alex_Y brings up an important idea: synchronizing the motors/synchronizing the motion.

Your capstan drive isn’t a positive drive; its going to migrate a little bit over time.  This is going to make the Falcon encoder to elevator position function change over time.

In over constrained systems like this one, keeping the right and left sides mechanically synchronized in critical for function; racking will make the system stop working!  I’m not sure how you are planning on attaching the ropes…  You should think carefully about your rigging in order to force the right and left sides to move together.

Load sharing and position control with the two separate drives may become a challenge.  Something to think about.  A belt loop between the two sides is a solid way to force the two Falcons to stay in step.
